items.definition: Count of conversations where the “Answers” module was triggered.

definition: The mode of agent handover for a bot conversation.
No agent handover == Conversation was not handed over to an agent.
Assigned to agent through direct transfer == TBD
Assigned to group during conversation == TBD
Assigned to agent due to fallback == Fallback flows will be triggered when the bot is not able to respond to the customer’s question.
Assigned to agent due to unhelpful feedback == Triggered when the user marks the bot response as unhelpful.

definition: Time taken after agent assignment to send the first response, considering the business hours. If no agent is assigned and the first response has been provided, the first response time will be calculated based on:
1. The time the conversation was initiated or,
2. The time the conversation was handed over by the bot.

items.definition: Time taken post-initiation to assign the conversation to a group.
Time taken post-initiation to assign the conversation to a group (only including business hours in time calculation).
Time taken post-initiation to assign the conversation to a group (only including business hours in time calculation).

The time from the first agent assignment to resolution. If the agent responded before assignment or if there's no agent assignment, it's the time from conversation creation or bot handover to resolution.
Time taken post-initiation to assign the conversation to an agent.
Time taken post-initiation, to assign the conversation to an agent (only including business hours in time calculation).

The time from the first agent assignment to the last agent response. If the agent responded before assignment or if there's no agent assignment, it's the time from conversation creation or bot handover to the last agent response.

Time taken to get the first response from the time the conversation was initiated, regardless of the business hours.

definition: Rounds up to the nearest integer.
Example: Convert revenue per unit to the next whole number (e.g., $23.01 → 24)
Rounds down to the nearest integer
Example: Used when you need a conservative minimum (e.g., discount rounding down)
Rounds to nearest integer or decimal precision
Example: Round a calculated average order value to 2 decimal places
Returns e^x (exponential)
Example: For growth modeling or decay calculations (e.g., exponential forecasting)
Returns the largest of a set of numbers
Example: Find highest score across multiple columns per record
Returns the smallest of a set of numbers
Example: Identify minimum inventory across multiple warehouses
Natural logarithm of a number
Example: Log transformation for statistical modeling or normalization
Raises one number to the power of another
Example: Calculate compound growth, e.g., POWER(1 + rate, time)
Square root
Example: ✅ Use case: Calculate distance, or root mean square. For example, SQRT(variance) to get standard deviation
Returns the middle value
Example: Useful for outlier-resistant central tendency (e.g., median purchase price)
Standard deviation
Example: Measure spread of values like user session times
Sample standard deviation
Example: Used when you’re analyzing a sample subset of the data
Most frequently occurring value
Example: Identify the most common product ordered
Returns a value at a given percentile
Example: PERCENTILE(sales, 0.9) gives value at 90th percentile
Statistical correlation between two fields
Example: See how strongly advertising spend correlates with sales
Sample variance
Example: Used when working with a statistical sample
Population variance
Example: Measure of spread for full datasets
Sample covariance
Example: See how two variables move together in a sample
Population covariance
Example: Like COVARIANCE_SAMP, but for a full population
Total number of rows or values
Example: Count number of transactions
Count of unique values
Example: Number of unique users
Count of null/blank values
Example: How many empty customer names in database
Count of non-empty values
Example: Number of products with prices entered
Returns first non-null value
Example: Use fallback if primary metric is null (e.g., COALESCE(profit_margin, default_value))
Format numbers as text
Example: Show 1,000,000 as “1M” or format decimals to 2 places
Checks if value lies within a range
Example: E.g., BETWEEN(sales, 1000, 5000)
Checks if outside a range
Example: Filter out data between thresholds
Checks if a value is null
Example: Use in conditional logic to fill gaps
Checks if a value is NOT null
Example: Include only complete records
Average of values
Example: Average revenue per customer
Highest value
Example: Max number of purchases
Lowest value
Example: Minimum cart value
Total sum
Example: Total sales
Synonym for SUM in some tools
Example: May act similarly depending on your BI tool
